title: Pensioner tortured partner for eight days after she asked him to turn down radio
text:
Watt was found guilty of assaulting his victim to the danger of her life at the High Court in Glasgow (Picture: PA Wire/PA Images)

A pensioner abducted and tortured his former partner for eight days after she asked him to turn down the radio.

Norman Watt, 67, was sentenced to six years in prison after admitting to subjecting his victim to a serious of violent assaults in a house in Old Mill Court in Leven, Fife, in 2018.

His sickening catalogue of abuse included striking his partner on the body with various objects – including a bottle, a walking stick, a knife and a belt – repeatedly burning her hand and attempting to burn her eyes with a lit cigarette.

He also choked her with a cardigan and a belt, bit her on the body, hit her with a table and punched her on the head and body until she lost consciousness.

The beatings apparently began when she asked Watt to turn the radio down to respect her elderly neighbours.

He responded by punching her on the face and body, and the violence escalated from there, with Watt smashing her phone to stop her from calling for help.

In another incident, Watt pushed a cushion over her face, placed his hand over her mouth, cut her face with glass and put his legs around her neck and compressed it.

His partner was rescued when a postman heard her pleas for help and noticed dried blood and bruises on her skin and blood splatters in the living room.

The victim was locked up in a house in Old Mill Court in Leven, Fife and subjected to horrific abuse (Picture: Google Maps)

Watt’s actions, which took place over an eight-day period between August 8 and 16, 2018, caused his victim severe injury, permanent disfigurement and danger to life.

The pair had been in a ‘volatile’ relationship’ in which alcohol and substance misuse was a major factor.

Watt faced an attempted murder charge which was later reduced by the Crown.

He initially told police that his former girlfriend was lying and her injuries were self-inflicted, but eventually admitted to assaulting her to the danger of her life.

Advocate Kevin McCallum said his client couldn’t remember the behaviour alleged but accepted responsibility for it.

Judge Lord Boyd told Watt at the High Court in Glasgow: ‘I have read her victim statement and it is clear what has happened has had a significant effect on her.’

Advertisement

Advertisement

He ordered Watt to serve six years imprisonment, backdated to August 29 when a guilty plea in relation to the assaults was tendered.

However, the judge added that he was satisfied he could impose a degree of leniency when sentencing due to certain factors.

Mr McCallum told the court that his client had cut all contact with the victim when he was released on bail in June and had gone to live with his daughter who was supporting him.

He added that he had been abstinent from alcohol and heroin for around a year.

The advocate also highlighted how the victim had sent Watt a Christmas card when released on bail in June, after spending eight months in prison due to a bail aggravation, that expressed her hope that he would be released.

He said: ‘It gives some indication that the complainer had mixed emotions or views at that time regarding how she felt about the accused.’

description: Pensioner Norman Watt tortured his partner for eight days after she asked him to turn down the radio in a house in Old Mill Court, Leven.
